New sets, costumes and props, plus digital projections give holiday classic a makeover

Actors Theatre refreshes 'A Christmas Carol'

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 9:18 a.m. EST December 11, 2014

A scene from the home of the Cratchit family in Actors Theatre of Louisville’s updated production of “A Christmas Carol.”(Photo: Photo by Bill Brymer.)

Story Highlights

  • 'A Christmas Carol'
  • When: Through Dec. 23.
  • Where: Actors Theatre of Louisville, Pamela Brown Auditorium, 316 W. Main St.
  • Cost: $25 to $75.
1 CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Transformation was at the center of "A Christmas Carol" when Charles Dickens wrote it. In the 171 years since, the saga of cold, greedy Ebenezer Scrooge who changes his life after being visited by three ghosts on Christmas Eve has never lost its luster.

The story has been made into plays, radio dramas and films, and since 1976 has been a mainstay of the Louisville area's holiday season with a long-running production at Actors Theatre of Louisville adapted by Barbara Field.

With this season's run of the holiday classic, Actors' production has undergone its own transformation, donning new set pieces, costumes and lighting, and even adding digital media to heighten the magic of the story.

The impulse to change the play's look came not long after Les Waters came to Actors as its artistic director three years ago. Waters said people involved in the production told him the set and costumes were suffering a fair share of wear and tear.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Dave Howard's Louisville Folk School connects past and future by teaching old-time music to new musicians.

Last year, he connected the production's director, Drew Fracher, with scenic designer Antje Ellermann. Waters had worked with Ellermann on many productions, starting in 2007 with a production of Irish playwright Martin McDonagh's "The Pillowman," which Waters directed at Berkeley Repertory Theatre.

Waters went on to work with her there on another McDonagh play, "The Lieutenant of Inishmore," as well as Will Eno's "Tragedy: a tragedy." The two also teamed up for Eno's premiere of "Middletown" at Steppenwolf Theatre Company. At Actors Theatre, Ellermann has designed sets for Eno's "Gnit," Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey into Night" and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins' "Appropriate."

"She's got a very strong sense of story — how a story should be told and how the physical setting can illuminate and move a story along," Waters said. "By nature, I think she is a minimalist and her work has a kind of elegance."

    In previous years at Actors, a large turntable rotated on stage to reveal Scrooge at his office, in his bedroom and viewing scenes of his past, present and future Christmases as shown to him by three ghosts.

    "It was huge and round and sort of cumbersome," said director Drew Fracher, who has directed Actors' production of "A Christmas Carol" since 2011. "It was also loud and ugly. It also put a big step in the middle of everything. So if you had a big dance, there was this step to work into the movement."

    And about a year ago, the first topic of conversation between Fracher and Ellermann about rebuilding "A Christmas Carol" was the big dance that Scrooge revisits via the Ghost of Christmas Past at the party given by Scrooge's employer from his youth — Mr. Fezziwig.

    "Drew was very keen on letting that be a big boisterous part and letting people really come together and have fun dancing. And it's a nice moment," said Ellermann, about seeing the production recently. "It made me think of how much fun it is to dance."

    But there is more to the stage. In the street scenes, there are buildings that span from stage left to right. When Scrooge is at home, his bed is a focal point of the stage with room for surprises, including ghosts that instantaneously appear on the stage.

    That's added more to the production for actor William McNulty, who was in Actors' first production of "A Christmas Carol" and has played Scrooge for 13 years.

    "In previous incarnations of the set, the bed seemed to be in a compartment. So, if you got into bed you couldn't be clearly seen by a portion of the audience. Now, it's in full view," McNulty said. "The bed is available to me as a playing area, especially after Marley visits in an intense and terrifying scene. The actor disappears right in from of my eyes, and the set allows me to let out a bloodcurdling scream, run to the bed and pull the covers over my face."

    The set also refers to the Victorian stage, McNulty pointed out, with a false proscenium arch, a big curtain that occasionally crosses the stage and footlights that resemble those that held candles during Dickens' era.

    "These little touches remind you of the time the story was written," McNulty added.

    Modern technology also has its place in the production, with digital projections designed by Philip Allgeier that help illustrate Scrooge's journeys with each of the ghosts. Allgeier was keen to be a part of the new production when Fracher approached him over the summer about adding digital media.

    "I loved the idea," Allgeier said. "I collected a lot of footage, and we created a lot of ways to use it. It was like a basketful of toys. But once we started trying them out, we realized that certain images triggered a modern sensibility even if it wasn't modern. Some animations were too much and felt too digital."

    A scene featuring part of the new set of Actors Theatre of Louisville’s updated production of “A Christmas Carol.”(Photo: Photo by Bill Brymer.)

    The animations that made it into the production, he said, were ones that felt like an extension of Scrooge's and Dickens' world.

    The production also called for new props by the theater's technical staff and new costumes by designer Kristopher Castle. They include rich fabrics, such as velvet, and bright colors. Each piece was made mostly by hand. Some pieces include embroidery, crochet and knitting, and all are designed to reflect the time of the scenes in which they appear — from those in the scenes that depict Scrooge's youth and those occurring nearly 50 years later, when he is undergoing an epiphany.

    Lighting designer Thomas C. Hase and sound designer Matt Callahan rounded out the production team working with Fracher and the others to make a production Waters is proud of.

    "I love it," he said. "They've done a wonderful job."

    His favorite parts?

    "I like the travel sequences a great deal, and Christmas Future makes me jump," Waters said. "That was a great design coup."

    Reporter Elizabeth Kramer can be reached at (502) 582-4682. Follow her on Twitter at @arts_bureau.

    IF YOU GO

    What: "A Christmas Carol," based on the book by Charles Dickens; adapted by Barbara Field; directed by Drew Fracher.

    When: Through Dec. 23.

    Where: Actors Theatre of Louisville, Pamela Brown Auditorium, 316 W. Main St.

    Cost: $25 to $75.

    Information: (502) 584-1205; www.actorstheatre.org.
